Pete,

I'm fairly certain you aren't referring to the
different Nobuiye (Akasaka Nobuiye, Myochin Nobuiye,
Owari Nobuiye, Echizen Nobuiye, etc). Jim or someone
else will comment best on this, but I was reading
through Haynes Catalogs last night and did come upon
across a section comparing 3 examples of 'Nobuiye
longmei'. Basically looks like his ana spacing left
him too narrow a space for his normal signature and he
consequently squeezed out his signature with one
character at the top and bottom V of area between the
two openings.
   I don't know how much of a variation this was
considered.

Curran
